titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the John White Geary Mexican War Papers
titlestmt.author: by Diana M. Smith

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: John White Geary Mexican War papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection consists of correspondence, military orders, muster rolls, and family material. Letters from John Geary's wife, Margaret, and brother, Edward, reflect political thinking on the national level. There is material from court martial proceedings, including the charges against Capt. Samuel H. Montgomery.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Frederick W. and Carrie S. Beinecke.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The John White Geary Mexican War Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: John White Geary Mexican War Papers. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Other Geary collections at the Beinecke are the John White Geary Papers (WA MSS 212), the John White Geary Business Papers (WA MSS S-209), and a letter from Geary to Major General Persifor Smith (WA MSS S-218).

bioghist.head: JOHN WHITE GEARY
bioghist.p: John White Geary was both soldier and politician; he served in the Mexican War and was later Territorial Governor of Kansas and Governor of Pennsylvania. At the outbreak of the Mexican War, Geary was Captain of the American Highlanders, which were attached to the "Cambria Legion." He and his company joined the 2nd Regiment of the Pennsylvania Volunteers at Pittsburgh, where he was elected Lieutenant Colonel. The regiment arrived at Vera Cruz April 11, 1847, via New Orleans and the Lobos Islands, and participated in Scott's advance to Mexico City. Colonel Roberts, the commander of the Regiment, was in such bad health that his responsibilities were left primarily to Geary. In the attack on Chapultepec Geary led the assault upon the fortress, and was placed in charge of this fortress upon its capture. Geary remained there on duty until the end of the war, being elected Colonel of his regiment on the death of Roberts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of correspondence, military orders, muster rolls, and family material. Letters from Geary's wife, Margaret, and brother, Edward, reflect political thinking on the national level. Captain Samuel H. Montgomery, a brother officer, sent letters back to Pennsylvania from Mexico in which he discredited the commander of the 2nd Regiment of Pennsylvania Volunteers, Colonel Roberts, and the officers under him, especially Geary. As these letters appeared in the Pennsylvania Argus , which was printed in Geary's home town of Greensburg, Pennsylvania, Geary's wife and brother were able to convey the public sentiment and reaction to the letters.

These papers also include a number of courts martial proceedings and sentences, including the charges preferred against Samuel H. Montgomery by Geary. There are also general military orders and reports which list the names of many of the men who deserted, were wounded, or killed in Geary's regiment.

An appended alphabetical listing of correspondents and dates of their letters is taken from the description of the Geary Mexican War Papers that appears as entry #93 in A Catalogue of the Frederick W. & Carrie S. Beinecke Collection of Western Americana compiled by Jeanne M. Goddard and Charles Kritzler (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1965). The correspondence is currently arranged chronologically; this appendix was included to enable readers to identify specific correspondents included in the collection.

odd.head: Appendix: Alphabetical List of Correspondents
odd.p: This listing is taken from the description of the Geary Mexican War Papers, entry #93 in A Catalogue of the Frederick W. & Carrie S. Beinecke Collection of Western Americana compiled by Jeanne M. Goddard and Charles Kritzler (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1965). The correspondence is currently arranged chronologically; this appendix was included to enable readers to identify specific correspondents within the collection.
Geary, John White. Copy of a letter to General George Gibson. July 20, 1847. Unsigned. 1 p.
---- Letter to Captain J. Hooker. January 31, 1848. 2 pp.
---- Charges and specifications preferred against Captain Samuel H. Montgomery, Assistant Quartermaster, U.S. Army. December 29, 1847. Signed by eight witnesses. 3 pp. With copy. 2 pp.
---- Copy of a letter to Major General Winfield Scott. October 31, 1847. Unsigned. 1 p.
---- Letter to His Excellency Francis Rawn Shunk. December 10, 1846. 1 p.
---- Copy of a letter to Daniel Sturgeon. 1847. Unsigned. 2 pp.
---- Letter to Major General Worth. October 29, 1847. 1 p.
---- Copy of a letter to Major General Worth. [n.d.] Unsigned. 2 pp.
---- Copy of a letter to George C. K. Zahm. [n.d.] Unsigned. 3 pp.
---- Report of the battle of Chapultepec to Lieutenant Lovell. September 15, 1847. 9 pp.
---- Copy of a letter for a plan for the consolidation of the 2d Regiment, Pennsylvania Volunteers. January 20, 1848. Unsigned. 1 p.
---- Anecdote of Santa Anna. [n.d.] Unsigned. 2 pp.
Armstrong, I. L. Letter to Geary. December 13, 1848. 1 p.
Armstrong, James. Letter to Geary. September 14, 1847. 1 p.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Series I, Correspondence , consists of incoming
and outgoing correspondence filed together. Many
of the letters are fragile; care should be taken
in handling them.
